data.text: Contents
Cancer governance and escalation arrangements ..................................................... 10
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (‘the Trust')) is committed to ensuring that patients receive treatment in accordance with the NHS Constitution, national objectives and targets, including ‘'achieving World Class Cancer Outcomes and the Long Term Plan.

This policy must be read in conjunction with the Trust's Cancer Access Policy. It sets out the Trust's rhythm for effective proactive and reactive escalation of cancer patients' pathway steps in order to achieve national cancer standards and achieve better clinical outcomes.

Patients' best interests are at the forefront of this policy. The timescales within which patients on a cancer pathway are treated is a vital quality issue and key indicator of the quality of cancer services offered at the Trust. In doing so, the Trust must meet the national Cancer Strategy standards and Cancer Waiting Times Guide version 11.
For patients, this policy will ensure that:

Patients with suspected cancer and/or with a confirmed cancer diagnosis receive treatment in accordance with the National Cancer Waiting Times relevant to their cancer pathway, taking into account that they may choose to wait longer or clinically be unable to be seen or treated within these time frames.
All patients are treated according to clinical priority and those with the same clinical priority are treated in chronological order.
For clinical and non-clinical staff, this policy will ensure that:
Teams and individuals are aware of their responsibilities for moving patients along the agreed clinical pathway in accordance with Cancer Waiting Times Guidance version 11.
Clinical support departments adhere to and monitor performance against agreed maximum waiting times for tests/investigations in their department.

Everyone involved in the Cancer pathway has a clear understanding of their roles and responsibilities, including the importance of timely communication both internally and externally, if transferred to other providers.

Accurate and complete data on the Trust's performance against the National Cancer Waiting Times is recorded in the Trust's Cancer Information System [currently Somerset Cancer Register Database (SCR)] and reported to the National Cancer Waiting Times Database (NHS Digital) within predetermined
timescales.
Scope

This policy applies to all Trust Staff involved in the care and management of cancer patients and to all patients with confirmed or suspected cancer cared for under Cancer Waiting Times Guidance as it applies to English NHS patients and as outlined in the Trust's Cancer Access Policy.
This policy does not cover patients who are seen, diagnosed and treated within 18 weeks from referral to treatment (RTT). Refer to the Trust's Patient Access Policy (MSEPO-20229 v1.1).
Definitions

table_items.text: This is where a diagnosis has been reached but it is not appropriate to give active treatment at that point in time but an active treatment is still intended/may be required at a future date.
The list of patients who are fit and able to be at that point in time. The active waiting lists is also used to report national waiting time statistics

If the trust cancels a patient's operation or procedure on the day of, or after admission for non-clinical reasons – the Trust is required to rearrange treatment within 28 days of the cancelled date or within target wait time whichever is soonest.

A CaRP form is designed by the cancer network to be completed when a patient's care is transferred between NHS trusts. A form provides information on the current pathway status of a patient, including the referral and breach dates.
The general principle that applies to patients categorised as requiring routine treatment. All routine patients should be seen or treated in the order they were initially referred for treatment.
Where a clinical decision is taken to treat a patient as an inpatient, day case or outpatient setting.
Patients who have agreed or been given reasonable notice of their appointment / treatment and who without notifying the Trust fail to attend.

An intervention intended to manage a patient's disease, condition or injury and avoid further intervention. What constitutes first definitive treatment is a matter of clinical judgment in consultation with other as appropriate, including the patient.

An MDT comprises of medical and non-medical professionals who are responsible for the cancer patient's care. It includes clinicians from a variety of disciplines, the exact constituent are described for each tumour site as part of Peer Review requirements
The three Trusts of Mid Essex; Southend and Basildon (‘the Trust' / ‘MSEFT')
Patients referred by a general practitioner (medical or dental) or another consultant / health professional for clinical advice or treatment.
Trust system where all patient appointments are booked and waiting lists are managed.

Patient Targeted List, a report used to ensure the maximum waiting time targets are achieved by identifying the patient wait time along their pathways and patients who are at risk of being outside the pathway requirements.
A system in which all cancer patients are tracked and monitored. SCR is also used to support our reporting processes. Referred to as the Approved Cancer Information System.
A proposed future date for an elective admission

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
Chief Executive

As the MSEFT Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the MSE has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Managing Director
As the Trust's Accountable Officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust provides appropriate and timely access to services for its patients.
Director of Operations - Cancer
Has strategic responsibility for the implementation of the Cancer Escalation Policy, monitoring compliance and reporting performance to the Trust Board.
Deputy Director of Operations - Cancer
Has strategic responsibility for the implementation of the Cancer Escalation Policy, monitoring compliance and reporting performance to the Trust Board.
General Manager Cancer
Is responsible for ensuring patient access procedural documents are appropriate, up to date and available when needed.
Cancer Service Delivery Manager
Is responsible for the overall performance of the Cancer Management Team, monitoring and overseeing the performance of the Multi-Disciplinary Team Co-ordinators.
Clinical Tumour Pathway Leads
Are responsible for ensuring staff are aware of, and adhere to this policy.
Deputy Director of Operations and Service Managers
Are accountable for compliance with this policy within their service areas on a daily basis.
Will be required to review their active pathway PTLs daily and identify next steps as set out in this policy in order to meet cancer national standards.
Investigate and respond when patients are escalated to them for action.
Escalate areas of concern affecting cancer patient pathways within their tumour site which require intervention from the Director of Operations.
Constantly review demand and capacity to meet national standards.

Provide solutions and redesign pathways (with support from the cancer services manager) to achieve the sustainable delivery of cancer standards e.g. reducing number of pathway steps, reducing time to first appointment, reducing the overall size of the PTL.
All Staff involved in the administration of patient appointments
Are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with and follow the Trust's policy and procedures relating to patient access.
Booking Clerk
All booking clerks must be aware of the specific milestones for the individual tumour sites.
Appointments must be booked within the specified timeframes.

Where appointments cannot be made within the specified timeframes escalation to the Service Manager for the relevant tumour site must be carried out before booking an appointment. This will prevent patients agreeing a breach date when an alternative solution could be found.
Escalation will be keeping within the specified timeframes in this policy.
If a patient cancels an appointment they should be rebooked as soon as possible.
MDT coordinators
Track patients thoroughly, accurately and consistently onto the cancer information system at least twice weekly. This is imperative as it directly impacts the effectiveness of the PTL meetings.

Prepare, coordinate attend and tie up MDT meetings fully ensuring all listed patients are discussed in a timely manner. Document MDT outcomes clearly and consistently onto the Cancer Information System.
Ensure data entry is complete and accurate, meeting all CWT and COSD guidelines (i.e. FDS, ICD Diagnosis codes, histology and radiology reporting)
Lead escalations at tumour site level as well as histology/ radiology
Highlight any concerns or delays to Cancer Management
Communicate effectively with service managers on updates on patients who are on active cancer pathway.
Attend cancer pre-PTL meetings with the tumour site service manager or assistant service manager and escalate issues as appropriate
Attend cancer PTL meetings and provide updates/MDT outcomes
Complete actions highlighted in the PTL meeting as per the timelines set out
in this policy.
Cancer Patient Pathway Tracker / MDT Assistant
Ensure patients are tracked thoroughly and accurately on the cancer information system twice per week as per “dynamic tracking”.
Ensure data entry is complete and accurate, meeting all CWT and COSD guidelines (i.e. FDS, ICD Diagnosis codes, histology and radiology reporting).
Monitor daily escalation lists (at tumour site level as well as histology/ radiology) and highlight concerns to management.
Deputise for the MDT coordinator in attending PTL meetings.
Assist with MDT preparation if required.
Cancer Navigator
Track patients from a service level – managing STT pathways, chasing consultants and histology/radiology/genetic testing to reduce unnecessary interactions between clinical teams and Cancer Team.
Contacting patients to chase tests and arrange appointments etc.
Input limited data into the cancer information system, i.e. first seen dates, investigation dates.
Attend Cancer PTL meetings where appropriate and provide updates where relevant.
Attend divisional meetings presenting cancer PTL data as appropriate.
Cancer governance and escalation arrangements
NB: all escalation timelines should be interpreted as working days throughout this policy.
Cancer pre-PTL meetings
Tumour-site meetings a day or two prior to the MSE Cancer PTL meeting should be held on a weekly basis, on the same day each week.
Chaired by the Deputy General Manager for Cancer Services
The purpose of the Cancer Pre-PTL meeting is to ensure:

It is important that the same format as the Cancer PTL meeting is followed for consistency. (See section 5.2). This includes a specialty-level review with patient-level enquiry, actions and follow through.

The meeting should include MDTC, Service Manager and/or Assistant Service Manager, Cancer Navigator or any other relevant member of staff as deemed appropriate by the Service Manager for the tumour site in question.
As a general rule, patients should be discussed, line by line, on the most challenged pathway(s).
Patients whose pathways are at risk of breaching key milestone targets should be discussed (either approaching the deadline without a date, or with a date beyond the deadline) for:
Escalation from pre-Cancer PTL  as a minimum: 2ww appointments, diagnostic appointments and reports, action pending MDT outcomes , TCI dates.
Cancer MSE PTL Meetings

The Cancer PTL Meeting must be held weekly at MSE Group/Director level review, and be chaired by the General Manager for Cancer responsible for the delivery of the cancer operational standards or nominee.
The meeting must be held on the same day each week to feed the escalation business rhythm of the Trust's cancer governance.
The meeting needs to be attended by the team with the operational responsibility for delivering the standards, the Cancer Service Delivery Manager (or deputy) and the MDTC.
It is good practice to have a clinician / member of the clinical team e.g. CNS to attend to assist with clinical queries and offer practicable solutions during the meeting.
It is also good practice for more senior operational staff e.g. associate director of operations to attend the meeting.
The Cancer PTL meetings must be action-orientated and focused upon:
Service Managers (or their deputies in their absence) should come to the meeting prepared (having attended the cancer pre-PTL meeting) to avoid distraction of staff having conflicting information.
The expectation is to go through patients from the longest wait down to  days, line-by-line in challenged pathways, and cover:
Updates on all patients must be led by the Service Manager.

Good administration (face to face or remote) is key to the smooth and effective running of the Cancer PTL meeting. Where possible, one patient is presented at a time on a screen, in a clear format highlighting as a minimum which and what day of the pathway they are on, as well as their breach date. Tracking notes for each patient must accurately depict the most up-to-date next step identified. Each tumour site must be allocated adequate time based on pathway challenges, number of pathways and PTL/Backlog size.

Actions must be captured accurately and sent across timely (at the end of each tumour site cancer PTL meeting) to either the service or the cancer administrative team e.g. data quality-related actions.

Service – allocated actions must be completed and responded to by close of play on the next working day. Incomplete actions will be escalated, via the cancer management team, to the relevant most senior Manager responsible for the service with a view of completing these actions by close of play on the next working day (two working days after the Cancer PTL meeting). If these actions have still not been completed by this deadline, they will be escalated to the associate director of operations responsible for those specialities.

Completion of actions and updates must be specific and effective as much as possible and practicable. E.g. if the action was to date a OPA, the update should provide a booking date for the OPA as opposed to mentioning that the bookings team have been contacted.
It is important that any agreed actions are followed through and reviewed the following week to ensure they have been addressed.
An audit trail of the actions and when they have been dealt with should be
kept.
Key escalations areas (for timeframes see appendix 1).
Outpatient first appointment capacity
If the Appointment Centre anticipates that an appointment cannot be made inside the relevant waiting time standards, this will be escalated to the relevant Service Manager or deputy within 24 hours.
All Escalations should be emailed in the first instance with copies to the Cancer MDT mailbox.
The Service Manager or deputy will acknowledge the escalation within 24 hours.
The specialty management team are expected to ensure that all avenues have been considered to give the patient an appointment with a maximum of 6 days after the receipt of the referral

If an appointment cannot be secured within  days, the relevant Service Manager or deputy will be responsible for informing the AD no later than 4 days following receipt of the referral, to allow time to consider alternative arrangements for that patient.
STT diagnostic capacity – Endoscopy
If the date of the test is 15 days or more from the request date this should be escalated to appropriate service manager or deputy.

If an appointment cannot be secured within  days, the relevant Service Manager or deputy will be responsible for informing the AD no later than 4 days following receipt of the referral, to allow time to consider alternative arrangements for that patient.
STT diagnostic capacity – Imaging

If an appointment cannot be booked within 14 days of the request date then the booking clerk needs to escalate this to the relevant Service Manager or deputy. If an appointment cannot be secured within 14 days, the relevant Service Manager or deputy will be responsible for informing the AD no later than 4 working days following receipt of the referral, to allow time to consider alternative arrangements for that patient.
First appointment/STT patients exercising choice

In the event that a breach of the 2ww standard (and resultant delay to a  day pathway) is expected due to a patient exercising their right to choose a date beyond  days, the relevant MDTC will escalate this at the weekly cancer PTL meeting where the CNS intervention will be considered.
Delays to diagnostic reporting

If histopathology tests remain unreported after 5 working days, the Cancer Services team will escalate overdue reporting to the General Manager of Pathology Services as per local communication arrangements.
If tests remain unreported within a further 2 working days the MDTC will escalate to Cancer Services Manager for reporting at the weekly Trust Performance Committee.
Imaging department reporting timescales will be reported at the site's diagnostic and elective access committee (or equivalent) weekly by the Imaging department.
Escalations should also be picked up in the cancer pre-PTL and PTL meetings.
First treatment capacity issues
A delay to first definitive treatment will be determined by an expected inability to meet the timescale between DTT and treatment date, as specified in the timed pathways.
The Cancer Services team will discuss any definitive treatment appointment delays or target breaches with the Central Booking Office in the first instance.

If the delay is not resolved within a maximum 2 working days the Cancer Services team will raise the issue with the relevant Service Manager or deputy and, if still not resolved within a further  hours, with the Cancer Services Manager for further escalation at site's weekly diagnostic and elective access committee (or equivalent).
Delays to tertiary treatments

In the first instance, delays to treatment at tertiary centres will be addressed at the relevant weekly virtual PTL meetings with partner organisations. This process will encompass an escalation between respective Cancer Services Managers at each organisation or site.

In the event that delays cannot be resolved within a suitable timeframe, and specifically, if there presents a risk that a shared patient will breach as the result of a delay at a tertiary centre, an escalation should take place via the site's weekly diagnostic and elective access committee (or equivalent), escalated via the site's elective care board (or equivalent) to the Chief Operating Officer to allow for this to be addressed between the two organisations.
Weekly MSE Tumour Site PTL Meeting (or equivalent) at the Cancer Board
Membership of Cancer PTL Management Meetings
Director of Operations - Cancer
Deputy Director of Operations – Cancer
Clinical Tumour Pathway Lead
Deputy Director of Operations – CG1, CG2 and CG3
General Managers – CG1, CG2 and CG3
Days and Time of Cancer PTL Management Meetings
The duration of the meeting will be 1 hour per Tumour Site but will be subject to change.
The day and time of the meetings needs to be confirmed by individual tumour site teams.
Expectations of meeting

The tumour site leads will have robust management in place to monitor and update the MSE PTL and send the information to the Director of Operations and Deputy Director of Operations  hours before the meeting within the template provided.
The data required will include but not exhaustive the following:
PTL size
PTL increase of decrease
2WW performance
31 day performance
62 day performance
Over 104 days
Patients with treatment dates
Patients waiting for treatment dates
Plans for backlogs
Breach numbers per month and month end
OPD capacity
Diagnostic capacity
JOC capacity
Theatre capacity
Prioritising treatments
Actions from this meeting will address themes and issues (local or at MSEFT level) affecting cancer performance and will be monitored week-on-week.

A highlight insight report will be produced from this meeting and presented at the System Service Improvement and Recovery Oversight Group (or equivalent). The insight report will also be discussed to address current issues on waiting lists, agreeing mutual prioritisation and providing remedial MSEFT solutions to issues affecting specific parts of the shared cancer pathway.

Findings, themes, resolutions and progress on actions from outputs of cancer MSEFT level meetings will also be presented at the MSEFT Cancer Board. The board will review past performance, future forecasts and predictions, flag and resolve critical issues.
Training requirements

All non/clinical staff will have Trust induction and PAS training. All non/clinical staff involved in cancer pathways will have specific local training in relation to the implementation of this policy and Somerset Cancer Register training provided by Cancer Services, supported by the Cancer Waiting list/MDT Managers. Additional or remedial training will be provided as required.
Monitoring and audit
This policy will be formally approved by the Senior Management Team and agreed with commissioning partners. Alterations and amendments to this policy will be approved and ratified by these bodies.

Issues around interruption and application of this policy will be initially resolved by General Manager for Cancer Services where any matter cannot be resolved at this level it will be escalated to the Cancer Service Board Group and Chief Operating Officer for resolution.
Compliance with this policy will be monitored as outlined in the Monitoring Compliance and Effectiveness section.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
National / statutory requirements on access to services are being met.
Daily pathway validation and production of monthly performance reports
Sample of patients from each tumour group
Cancer Data Quality Officer or equivalent
Tertiary referral dates validated with referring Trust
Cancer information manager/ Cancer service manager

data.text: Compliance with this policy will be monitored as set out below;
Weekly validation checks as part of Cancer PTL review.

Monthly validation checks -All data fields are completed and submitted as required Totals are correct – e.g. that the total is a sum over all treatment functions large changes in volumes compared to previous months will be investigated.
Quarterly validation checks.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Cancer Task and Finish Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local cancer guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Cancer Task and Finish Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)

Appendix 2: Equality impact assessment
If you have identified any negative impact in the preliminary analysis above, please complete this full Equality Impact Assessment.

Based on the results of consultation, any data or research you have considered, please record and evidence your analysis of the implications of organisational or service change for the various groups of people affected. Please be specific about how you have arrived at your conclusion in relation to impact. Please describe the analysis undertaken and interpretation of evidence. N/A

table_items.text: Please consider any impact that the changes may have on people because of:
Is there potential for negative impact? YES or NO
Are there opportunities for positive impact? YES or NO
Please give details of negative impact
Please give details of positive impact
Race or culture e.g. people who are black or from a minority ethnic background (BME), gypsies and travellers
Age e.g. older or younger people
Disability e.g. learning disabilities, physical disability, sensory impairment and mental health problems
Gender (e.g. women, men, people who are transitioning

married or in a civil partnership, those with caring responsibilities e.g. for children or adult dependents

data.text: Full Equality Impact Assessment undertaken by:
Decision:
Accept the proposal - no evidence of discrimination and/or opportunities to advance equality identified
Adjust the proposal - take steps to remove barriers (detail to be completed on the following page)
Continue the proposal - despite potential adverse effects the proposals do not unlawfully discriminate or there is objective justification
Stop the proposal – the policy show unlawful discrimination and adverse effects that cannot be mitigated
For each impact identified, please complete the following section:

table_items.text: Can the impact be avoided? YES/NO
If yes, what action will you take to avoid the impact? Include: - Action to be taken - Person responsible - Timescale - Monitoring arrangements
If you cannot avoid the impact, is there an objective justification? [see guidance below]

data.text: Objective Justification

In some cases, it may be that we cannot avoid doing something which may affect some people more than others. However this should be very rare. If you think this is the case, please consider the following:
Could you achieve the same aim in a different way?
Appendix 3: Additional template for use with proposals which impact on staff
1) Does the proposed change put staff at risk of redundancy or significant change e.g. relocation, major changes to working hours or patterns? Yes/No
2) If yes, please record details of all staff potentially affected in the table below:

table_items.text: The proposed changes are designed to ensure that there is greater staff cover across the week. This would mean John working shorter days which would mean him travelling in during rush hour rather than coming in early and leaving late as he does at present. He travels by public transport as he does not have a car and this may affect him adversely as trains are more crowded during peak hours and this creates greater difficulties for wheelchair users.

data.text: 1) What are the proposed criteria for selecting staff for any new post? (Criteria may include performance history, competence based interview, test, attendance records, disciplinary record. All decisions on appointment and selection procedures, identification of ‘at risk' staff and redundancy criteria must be fair and transparent, wherever possible competence based and compliant with equalities legislation.)
2) Would there be any staff who could be discriminated against as a result of the selection criteria proposed? Yes/No
3) If yes, please list what actions you will take to mitigate the impact
Assessment undertaken by:

This assessment relates to: Cancer escalation policy / MSEPO-21192 (Please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Create one cancer escalation policy (amalgamation of 3 cancer access policies)
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
One overarching MSEFT policy to ensure cancer escalation rules are consistent across MSEFT.
Who benefits from this change and how?
Consistency in cancer escalation by following one policy.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – this follows national guidance which all staff have to follow.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
